I hearde the mountaine gods complaine,</br>Sweet Willy thou neglects thy straine,</br>And that thou wouldst not blesse againe</br>Thy fellow swaine.
The sisters did bewaile,</br>That hee whose notes did oft assaile</br>Apollos skill, yea did prevaile,</br>Their art disdaines.
What if some forward stub-chind boy</br>Takes upp a reed, and dos employ</br>His artlesse lipps, can this annoy</br>Thy sweeter song?
Could thy exactnesse brooke a foile,</br>Without disparagement; their soile</br>Commends thy tounge more smoothe than oile,</br>Our sports amonge.
Great Pan eer since thou wentst away,</br>Has mist the glories of his day,</br>No shepheard dares begin a lay</br>To honor him.
Behold how all our joyes do turne</br>To sadnesse, see hot sighs which burne</br>Our brests, look how our swolne eyes mourne</br>And weepe till drie.
Our crooks are trailed along the ground,</br>Our pipes grow dumb, or sadly sound,</br>No flowrie chaplets eer hath crownd,</br>Since thine a browe.
Each shepheardesse as in despaire,</br>Mean more to be proclaimed faire,</br>T' fitt time to trim her fluent haire</br>Doth scarce allow.
Our lambs doe leave to skipp about,</br>And ape their dames sad pace throughout,</br>The hills with woes, as if they doubt</br>Securitie.
Now thou art absent, whose smooth reed</br>Did in the woulfs and tigers breed</br>A nature tame, and thus them freed</br>From crueltie.
Each muse, godd, sheep, and shepheards all,</br>Joyn in the art thy madrigall,</br>For Pans sake at thy festivall</br>Renew thy straines.
Why should that spright which sored so hie</br>Above the ken of emulous eye,</br>Eer Doridon be finishd die,</br>And shun our playnes.</br>
